oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Curly Putman Interview by John Lomax III Side Two
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is an interview of Curly Putman by John Lomax III. The interview takes place on 10-26-1981.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Curly Putman;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side Two - (0:03) -- Curly Putman continues discussion of his co-writing and learning from other songwriters. (0:33) -- Curly Putman describes the type of person he prefers to write with. (1:34) -- Curly Putman speaks about Bobby Braddock's preference for songwriting. (1:50) -- Curly Putman mentions that he often co-writes when he is in a hurry to get a song out. (2:07) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about his sons' interest in writing and playing music. (2:40) -- Curly Putman mentions playing steel guitar in a band in Alabama before he got into songwriting. This background helped his transition from performer to songwriter. (3:22) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about his marriage. (4:18) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about his long history with BMI. Curly Putman compliments Frances W. Preston. (5:08) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about his songwriting schedule with Bobby Braddock. (6:10) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about his interest in the evolving types of country music. (7:53) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman how a young writer may begin working with a respected publishing company such as Tree Publishing Company. (9:04) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about winning 'Song Of The Year' two years in a row. (10:07) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about whether he stills pitches his own tunes. Curly Putman mentions that he still pitches tunes occasionally. (10:52) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about whether he thinks he has songs that have been overlooked compared to his other popular compositions. (11:58) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about a songwriter's presence at a recording session. (13:22) -- John Lomax asks Curly Putman about what makes a great country song compared to other genres. Curly Putman mentions that a great country song has superb longevity.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Putman, Curly;
